issue.title: Serialization needs to account for _any_ type of object being an Attribute value

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.body:
Recently it was discovered (https://3v4l.org/VEQer) that you can new objects in Attributes. This represents a significant departure from assumptions that this library made in 1.x regarding Attribute values. Several things would not currently work in 1.x properly if you provided a "complex" object to Attribute values. Of particular import here is the `InjectDefinition` and corresponding `Inject` attribute which is designed to take arbitrary values.

In 2.0 this should be handled more properly by acknowledging that complex objects can be passed in Attributes that should be cacheable. A lot of considerations are going to come into play with this and we should ensure the API for injecting these type of complex values is well defined and understood.

issue.title: Ensure that Configuration objects respect constructor-promoted properties

milestone.title: v1.x Release
milestone.description: The Big Container Push. This release is focused primarily on integrating as many backing Container libraries as possible.

issue.title: Add a method on each definition that returns ?ObjectType<Attribute>

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.body:
There might be reasons for a definition to need to know what attribute was used for reasons other than just creating the container. We should expose, at the minimum, which Attribute type was used to determine the definition. Since it might be possible for a definition to come from the functional API we should also account for it being null.

This would represent a significant change to existing interfaces that this requires a major version release.

issue.title: RFC: Add start() and stop() methods to HttpServer interface (v3+)
issue.body:
I'm digging into the 3.0 beta and from a testing perspective I appreciate the HttpServer interface. It allows to more easily write unit tests in addition to integration tests. However, this interface does not include methods to start and stop the server, limiting its usefulness from a testing perspective.

Are the maintainers open to including the existing start() and stop() methods on the `SocketHttpServer` in the `HttpServer` interface?
